strings.Value: Frowned, bared {mf|his|her} weapons, and charged into battle.
Smiled, muttered "why not," and took a place near the fire.
Spat on the ground and moved on.
Laughed and accepted the invitation.
Bravely filled the keg from the barrel.
Firmly rejected drinking THIS.
Drained the first keg to its dregs.
Was already going to sip, but smelled the ale, shook {mf|his|her} head, and poured the beverage back in the barrel.
"Why not!"
"I'm too tired to sing. You sing, I'll listen."
Goblin lasses be all impressed!
And Lamashtu be impressed.
And pass all your stupid tests.
Get away from me, you pest!
Um, do I really have to rhyme here?
Is to kill! And kill! And kill!
Is that his belly's hard to fill.
Is to ransack a windmill.
Hey, you, I want my mug refill!
Scream like hell and run away!
Quickly hide and sneak away!
Kiss your life farewell and pray.
Tell him you wants to parley!
Do a belly dance!
So, a toast to Goblin King!
We stay here till next spring!
By the way, your ale stinks.
And pull each other's nose rings, ha ha.
Hic! What?
And your belly will stay fulls.
To be smarts and no fools.
Also, learn to wipe your drools.
Pass me another keg, would you?
Close.
Finally, the song was over.
Drained the second keg.
Drained the last keg.
Close.
Ugh. To annoy people, I guess?
Also, never skip your schools.
Kicked the dog and took the plate.
Answered that {mf|he|she} didn't feel like it.
Snuck up to the plate to snatch it from under the hound's nose.
Took the plate, ignoring the dog completely.

While passing the windmill, we saw a curious thing. Goblins were squatting in the shadow of the building, doing what goblins do best — stuffing their faces. They had gutted sacks of flour and were spreading the wealth — some fried pancakes on an open fire, others threw pieces of dough into a bubbling pot making some kind of dumplings, yet others just rolled around in the white powder, shoving clumps down their throats. All of them, without exception, were guzzling ale from kegs nearby, spilling it over each other and bellowing songs. When they spotted us, the merry goblins — possibly due to the ale — stood their ground. Instead of fleeing, they started to whistle and wave, inviting us to join their feast. In response, the {mf|baron|baroness}...

I'd never been at a goblin party before — but it proved little different from the late-night {g|Academy of Grand Arts}Academy{/g} reveries. Using their crippled speech, the flour-drenched merry-goers explained the miller invited them to his house, told them to take whatever they wanted, and was 'polite' enough not to ruin the fun — and left soon after that. The food tasted as foul as to be expected, but ale was passable, so soon all of us were tipsy. After these little troublemakers unmistakably recognized {mf|baron|baroness} as our leader, they offered {mf|him|her} to pass several tests to become, um, part of the tribe. For the first test they demanded {mf|him|her} to deal with a terrible beast — the dog (goblins and dogs, well... they don't get along — neither with horses, and... well almost any animal that doesn't sting, bite, or hiss). The {mf|Baron's|Baroness'} task was to steal the miller dog's food plate. So, {mf|he|she}...

The barrel smelled horrible. The goblins were scooping the ale in their dirty hands, and when that proved not enough, they dipped their entire heads in, fishing toads out the barrel, with their teeth, licking the toads' ale-blistered skins, and tossing them back in. The {mf|baron|baroness}...

The dog proved rather big, but lazy and quiet. It was slumbering in the kennel, paying no heed to the nearby party. The dog's plate, covered in bones, lay before the kennel. The {mf|baron|baroness}...
It was the perfect crime — as silent as a shadow, {mf|baron|baroness} swept up the plate. The dog didn't stir.
Noticing someone trying to steal its plate, the dog opened its eyes. It raised its head, gave a half-hearted bark, then laid its head back on the ground and closed its eyes.
With a yelp, the dog leapt up and fled with its tail between its legs. The goblins cheered and whistled as it ran off.

After the goblins praised the {mf|baron|baroness} for {mf|his|her} brilliant performance during the first test, they announced it was time for {mf|him|her} to taste their ritual drink — a really nasty thing called "jagwart." At first glance, it proved to be ale... until we saw the dead toads bobbing in the barrel for "flavor." Judging by the toads' color, they were poisonous. After the {mf|baron|baroness} saw the brew and smelled it, {mf|he|she}...

The goblins burst into laughter, applauded and announced that the {mf|baron|baroness} has passed the first task brilliantly — just like a "real goblin." (Apparently, if a real goblin doesn't feel like passing some stupid test, he'd never do it, especially if it demands they stop eating and drinking.)

The goblins did not insist — the laziness in their pantheon seemed to be at least as important as {g|Lamashtu}Lamashtu{/g} herself. Without making us join along, they started to shout a song — it was so loud, atonal, and odd, that it couldn't be written down by anyone short of a master ethnographer, who really loves their job.
Goblins didn't like the rhyme — instead of singing on, they started to whistle, and throw flour at us… and each other. In a heartbeat, the impromptu concert turned into a skirmish.

Finally the food and ale were exhausted. Casting sad glances at the empty sacks and barrels, an elder goblin sighed and started a speech about how he remembered the happy old times when they were full, but no one seemed to be listening. As the old goblin rambled on, another goblin, slurring his words, invited us to the next party in their village, and (after many false starts) gave us directions on how to reach it — a dubious honor, indeed, but a useful bit of information! After that, the sodden merry-goes stumbled away, burping and licking their fingers happily.
My ears almost bled from the rhymes, but the {mf|baron|baroness} kept calm — to the goblins utter joy, {mf|he|she} finished the song, and got a standing ovation as a reward!
I'd drop dead just having smelled it, but the {mf|baron|baroness} downed the horrific beverage without even wincing. Clapping their hands, goblins brought {mf|him|her} another keg. {mf|He|She}…

The {mf|Baron|Baroness} turned pale, drops of sweat appeared on {mf|his|her} forhead, but {mf|he|she} drained the second keg without complaint. But those little bastards seemed determined to send {mf|him|her} to an early grave — they were already handing {mf|him|her} the third keg. The {mf|Baron|Baroness}...

I bet {mf|his|her} stomach was lined with dwarven steel — after the third keg of the horrific swill, the {mf|baron|baroness} grunted, wiped {mf|his|her} lips, and smashed the keg over the nearest goblin's head, making others laugh and applaud.

The {mf|Baron's|Baroness'} face turned pale, then red, {mf|his|her} eyes brimming with tears. Unable to keep it down, {mf|he|she} spat the horrible beverage into some goblin's face and started to cough. The goblins hurried to whack {mf|Baron's|Baroness'} back, laughing — either to help {mf|him|her} to clear {mf|his|her} throat, or congratulating {mf|him|her} on passing another test.

"Now be third test!" The goblins howled and cheered — it seems they decided they had tortured the art of cooking enough for the day, so now they sought to abuse the art of poetry instead. They were going to sing a song, and {mf|baron|baroness} was offered to improvise and add the missing lines. {mf|He|She} answered...
Shrieking, the goblins scattered and ran, kicking up clouds of flour. When the cloud settled, of the goblins there was no sign.
The goblins weren't offended. Laughing and screaming, they bellowed, "more for us!" Then they started to slurp that dreadful swill — one of them even dived into the barrel to bob amongst the toads.
Goblin lasses be all impressed!
And {g|Lamashtu}Lamashtu{/g} be impressed.
Is to kill! And kill! And kill!
That his belly's hard to fill.
Quickly hide and sneak away!
Scream to the hells and run away!
So, a toast to Goblin King!
We stay here till next spring!
And your belly will stay fulls.
To be smarts and no fools.
Drained the last keg.
Drained the second keg.
Drained the first keg to the dregs.

Goblins sing for you this song
How be smart and fit and strong
How be the goblin best

Goblins fight and goblins bite
Goblins steal and goblins hide
But the bestest goblin skill

Manticore deep in the wood
Eats goblins for food, not good
So as not to be his prey

Goblin King be strong and wise
Manticore he want, full-sized!
But we better eat and drink

Goblins sang this song to you
If you be a goblin new
Always heed these simple rules
After the song was over, the goblins laughed and applauded.
Accompanying the song with percussions (percussions were everything the goblins could reach — sticks, branches, forks, pans) they started to croak out a rhythm — as well as they were able.
